questions.question: Physical presence nexus for state income tax is established when a business has:

options.A: Only online sales to state residents
options.B: Employees, property, or regular physical presence in the state
options.C: A single transaction in the state

questions.explanation: Traditional physical presence nexus requires employees, property (owned or leased), or regular physical presence in a state. This includes offices, warehouses, inventory, traveling salespeople, and service personnel. Many states now also impose economic nexus based on sales thresholds.
questions.tip: Physical nexus = people or property in the state. Economic nexus = sales threshold (no physical presence required).

questions.question: The South Dakota v. Wayfair Supreme Court decision (2018) held that states may require:

options.A: All businesses to collect sales tax regardless of nexus
options.B: Remote sellers to collect sales tax based on economic nexus without physical presence
options.C: Only in-state businesses to collect sales tax
options.D: The federal government to administer state sales taxes

questions.explanation: Wayfair overturned the physical presence requirement for sales tax nexus (from Quill). States can now require remote sellers to collect sales tax based on economic nexus (typically $100,000 in sales or 200 transactions). Most states have adopted economic nexus laws following Wayfair.
questions.tip: Wayfair = economic nexus for sales tax. Physical presence no longer required. Check each state's thresholds.

questions.question: State conformity to federal tax law means:

options.A: All states use identical tax rates
options.B: States adopt federal definitions of income, deductions, or taxable income as a starting point
options.D: State taxes are deductible on federal returns

questions.explanation: State conformity means states adopt federal definitions (AGI, taxable income, depreciation methods) as a starting point for calculating state tax. States may conform to current federal law (rolling conformity) or a fixed date (static conformity). States then add modifications.
questions.tip: Conformity = federal starting point with state modifications. Rolling vs. static conformity varies by state.

questions.question: The TCJA limited the itemized deduction for state and local taxes (SALT) to:

options.A: $5,000 for all filers
options.B: $10,000 ($5,000 for married filing separately)
options.D: No limit for primary residence property taxes

questions.explanation: TCJA limited the SALT deduction to $10,000 ($5,000 for MFS) for tax years 2018-2025. This includes state and local income taxes (or sales taxes if elected) plus property taxes combined. This cap significantly impacted taxpayers in high-tax states.
questions.tip: SALT cap = $10K total (income/sales + property taxes combined). Expires after 2025.

questions.question: Income apportionment formulas are used by states to:

options.A: Determine which state receives all of a business's tax
options.B: Allocate a multistate business's income among states where it has nexus

questions.explanation: Apportionment formulas divide a multistate business's income among states where it has nexus, ensuring each state taxes only its fair share. Traditional formulas use property, payroll, and sales factors. Many states now use single sales factor apportionment.
questions.tip: Apportionment = divide income among states. Most states moving to single sales factor.

questions.question: Property taxes are generally based on:

options.A: The property owner's income
options.B: The assessed value of real and personal property
options.C: The original purchase price of the property

questions.explanation: Property taxes are ad valorem taxes based on the assessed value of property (real property and sometimes tangible personal property). Assessment methods vary by jurisdiction but typically involve market value, income approach, or cost approach. Tax = assessed value × mill rate.
questions.tip: Property tax = assessed value × rate. Assessment methods and rates vary widely by locality.

questions.question: A common economic nexus threshold for sales tax collection is:

options.A: $10,000 in sales or 50 transactions
options.B: $100,000 in sales or 200 transactions

questions.explanation: Following Wayfair, most states adopted the South Dakota threshold: $100,000 in sales OR 200 transactions in the state. Some states eliminated the transaction threshold or have different sales thresholds. Businesses must monitor nexus in each state where they sell.
questions.tip: Common threshold: $100K sales or 200 transactions. But thresholds vary by state - always verify.

questions.question: States using single sales factor apportionment benefit businesses that:

options.A: Have most of their sales in that state
options.B: Have significant property and payroll in that state but sell mostly elsewhere

questions.explanation: Single sales factor apportionment bases state tax entirely on the percentage of sales in that state. Businesses with heavy property and payroll in a state but sales primarily elsewhere pay less state tax than under traditional three-factor formulas. This is why many states adopted single sales factor - to attract employers.
questions.tip: Single sales factor benefits employers (property/payroll in state, sales elsewhere). Hurts pure sales-in-state businesses.

questions.question: Most states exempt from sales tax:

options.A: All services
options.B: Sales for resale and sales to exempt organizations

questions.explanation: Common sales tax exemptions include sales for resale (to avoid pyramiding tax), sales to nonprofits and government entities, manufacturing equipment, and certain necessities (groceries, prescription drugs in many states). Services are taxable in some states but exempt in others.
questions.tip: Resale exemption prevents tax pyramiding. Nonprofits and government usually exempt. Service taxability varies.

questions.question: Use tax is designed to:

options.A: Tax services that are not subject to sales tax
options.B: Complement sales tax by taxing purchases where sales tax was not collected
options.D: Replace income tax for certain transactions

questions.explanation: Use tax complements sales tax by taxing the use, storage, or consumption of tangible personal property when sales tax was not collected (e.g., out-of-state purchases, purchases from non-collecting sellers). Use tax prevents avoidance of sales tax through out-of-state purchases.
questions.tip: Use tax = backup to sales tax. Applies when sales tax wasn't collected. Same rate as sales tax.

questions.question: Pass-through entity taxes (PTETs) allow:

options.A: Pass-through entities to avoid all state taxes
options.B: Owners to effectively deduct state taxes above the $10,000 SALT cap
options.C: Conversion of state taxes to federal taxes

questions.explanation: PTETs allow pass-through entities (S corps, partnerships) to elect to pay state income tax at the entity level. The entity gets a deduction (not subject to SALT cap), and owners receive a credit or exclusion on their individual returns. IRS Notice 2020-75 approved this workaround.
questions.tip: PTET = SALT cap workaround. Entity pays state tax, gets full deduction. Owner gets credit/exclusion.

questions.question: The difference between allocation and apportionment is that allocation:

options.A: Divides income using a formula based on factors
options.B: Assigns specific types of income (like interest, dividends) entirely to one state

questions.explanation: Allocation assigns specific categories of nonbusiness income (interest, dividends, rents, royalties, capital gains from nonbusiness assets) entirely to one state, typically the taxpayer's domicile or where the income-producing property is located. Apportionment divides business/operational income among states using a formula.
questions.tip: Allocate = assign 100% to one state (nonbusiness income). Apportion = divide by formula (business income).

questions.question: A statutory resident of a state is typically an individual who:

options.A: Was born in the state
options.B: Maintains a permanent place of abode and spends more than 183 days in the state
options.C: Works in the state for any period

questions.explanation: Statutory residency rules (varying by state) typically treat an individual as a resident if they maintain a permanent place of abode in the state AND spend more than 183 days there. This can result in dual residency situations where an individual is taxed as a resident by multiple states.
questions.tip: Statutory resident = permanent abode + 183+ days. Can be resident of multiple states simultaneously.

questions.question: Combined reporting requires affiliated corporations to file as one if they are:

options.A: All headquartered in the same state
options.B: Engaged in a unitary business (functional integration, centralized management, economies of scale)

questions.explanation: Combined reporting states require corporations that are part of a unitary business to file combined returns. A unitary business exists when there is functional integration, centralized management, and economies of scale among affiliated entities. This prevents income shifting among affiliates.
questions.tip: Unitary business = functional integration + centralized management + economies of scale. Prevents income shifting.

questions.question: Market-based sourcing assigns service and intangible income to:

options.A: Where the service is performed
options.B: Where the customer receives the benefit of the service

questions.explanation: Market-based sourcing assigns service income to where the customer receives the benefit (the market state), rather than where the service is performed (cost-of-performance). Most states have moved to market-based sourcing for services. This can significantly impact service businesses.
questions.tip: Market-based = where customer is. Cost-of-performance = where work done. Major impact on service companies.

questions.question: Marketplace facilitator laws require:

options.A: Individual sellers to collect sales tax on all marketplace sales
options.B: The marketplace (Amazon, eBay, etc.) to collect and remit sales tax on behalf of third-party sellers
options.C: Buyers to self-assess use tax on marketplace purchases
options.D: Marketplaces to report seller income to the IRS

questions.explanation: Marketplace facilitator laws shift sales tax collection responsibility from individual sellers to the marketplace platform (Amazon, eBay, Etsy). The marketplace collects and remits tax on sales made through its platform, simplifying compliance for small sellers.
questions.tip: Marketplace facilitator = platform collects tax for third-party sellers. Most states have adopted these laws.

questions.conceptTested: Credit for Taxes Paid to Other States
questions.question: A credit for taxes paid to other states prevents:

options.A: States from imposing any income tax
options.B: Double taxation when income is taxed by both a resident and nonresident state
options.D: Businesses from operating in multiple states

questions.explanation: Resident states typically provide a credit for income taxes paid to other states on income sourced to those states. This prevents double taxation when income is taxed by both the residence state (worldwide taxation) and the source state (where income is earned).
questions.tip: Credit for other state taxes = resident state credit for nonresident taxes paid. Prevents double taxation.

questions.question: Public Law 86-272 protects sellers from state income tax if their only activity in a state is:

options.A: Any type of sales activity
options.B: Solicitation of orders for tangible personal property, approved outside the state
options.D: Maintaining a website accessible to state residents

questions.explanation: P.L. 86-272 prohibits states from imposing income tax on sellers whose only in-state activity is soliciting orders for tangible personal property, with orders approved and shipped from outside the state. It does not apply to services, intangibles, or sales tax. Many states interpret this narrowly.
questions.tip: P.L. 86-272 = income tax protection for mere solicitation of TPP sales. Doesn't cover services or sales tax.

questions.question: Throwback rules require sales to be sourced to the seller's state when:

options.A: The buyer is in another country
options.B: The seller is not taxable in the destination state
options.D: The sale is made through a marketplace

questions.explanation: Throwback rules source sales to the seller's (origin) state if the seller is not taxable in the destination state. This prevents 'nowhere income' - sales that would escape taxation entirely. Not all states have throwback rules; some have throwout rules instead.
questions.tip: Throwback = source to seller's state if not taxable in buyer's state. Prevents nowhere income.

questions.question: Business personal property taxes typically apply to:

options.A: Real estate only
options.B: Inventory only
options.C: Equipment, furniture, fixtures, and sometimes inventory

questions.explanation: Many states and localities impose property tax on tangible personal property used in business - equipment, furniture, fixtures, machinery, and in some states, inventory. Businesses must file personal property renditions listing taxable assets. Rates and rules vary significantly by jurisdiction.
questions.tip: Business personal property tax = equipment, furniture, fixtures. Inventory taxable in some states. File annual renditions.

questions.question: Destination-based sourcing means sales tax is imposed:

options.A: Where the seller is located
options.B: Where the buyer takes delivery or receives the product

questions.explanation: Destination-based sourcing imposes sales tax based on where the buyer takes possession or where the product is delivered. Most states use destination sourcing. Origin-based sourcing (fewer states) taxes based on where the seller is located. This affects which rate applies.
questions.tip: Destination sourcing (most states) = buyer's location rate. Origin sourcing = seller's location rate.

questions.question: State tax incentives for businesses typically include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: Investment tax credits for new equipment
options.B: Job creation credits

questions.explanation: States offer various incentives: investment tax credits, job creation credits, property tax abatements, sales tax exemptions for manufacturing equipment, and income tax credits. States cannot reduce federal tax rates - that's solely federal jurisdiction. Incentives require compliance with job/investment commitments.
questions.tip: State incentives: job credits, investment credits, property abatements, sales tax exemptions. No federal rate control.

questions.question: Factor presence nexus for income tax is established when a business exceeds thresholds for:

options.A: Physical presence only
options.B: Property, payroll, or sales in the state above certain amounts
options.C: Number of customers in the state

questions.explanation: Factor presence nexus creates income tax nexus when property, payroll, or sales in a state exceed certain thresholds (often $50,000-$500,000 depending on the state and factor). This is an economic nexus concept for income tax, parallel to Wayfair's sales tax nexus.
questions.tip: Factor presence = economic nexus for income tax. Based on property, payroll, or sales thresholds.

questions.question: The classification of income as business (apportionable) versus nonbusiness (allocable) depends on:

options.A: The source of the income
options.B: Whether the income arises from the taxpayer's regular trade or business operations

questions.explanation: Business income (apportioned) arises from the taxpayer's regular trade or business operations (transactional test) or from assets used in the business (functional test). Nonbusiness income (allocated 100% to one state) is from activities unrelated to the business. Classification significantly affects state tax.
questions.tip: Business income = from regular operations or business assets → apportion. Nonbusiness = unrelated → allocate.

questions.question: A water's edge election in combined reporting limits the combined group to:

options.A: Corporations headquartered in coastal states
options.B: U.S. corporations and certain foreign corporations with U.S. connections
options.C: Only corporations with physical presence in the state

questions.explanation: Water's edge elections limit the combined group to U.S. corporations, domestic international sales corporations (DISCs), foreign sales corporations (FSCs), and foreign corporations deriving significant income from U.S. sources or connected with U.S. trade or business. This excludes purely foreign operations.
questions.tip: Water's edge = U.S. entities + foreign with U.S. connections. Excludes purely foreign operations from combined return.

questions.question: Unclaimed property (escheat) laws require businesses to:

options.A: Pay income tax on unclaimed amounts
options.B: Report and remit dormant property (uncashed checks, unused gift cards) to the state
options.C: Write off unclaimed amounts as bad debts

questions.explanation: Escheat laws require businesses to report and remit unclaimed property (uncashed payroll checks, vendor payments, customer refunds, unused gift cards) to the state after a dormancy period. Priority rules determine which state receives the property. Non-compliance results in penalties and interest.
questions.tip: Escheat = remit dormant property to state. Priority: owner's last known address, then state of incorporation.

questions.question: The sales tax treatment of software varies by state, with many states distinguishing between:

options.A: Business and personal use software
options.B: Canned (prewritten) software and custom software
options.D: Software sold to residents and nonresidents

questions.explanation: States often distinguish between canned (prewritten) software (often taxable as tangible personal property) and custom software (often exempt as a service). SaaS (cloud-based software) treatment varies widely - some states tax it, others don't. Delivery method (download vs. physical) may also affect taxability.
questions.tip: Software tax varies: canned often taxable, custom often exempt. SaaS treatment inconsistent across states.

questions.question: Related-party add-back statutes require taxpayers to:

options.A: Add related parties to their combined return
options.B: Add back deductions for royalties, interest, or management fees paid to related parties

questions.explanation: Add-back statutes combat income shifting by requiring taxpayers to add back deductions for certain payments (royalties, interest, intangible expenses, management fees) to related parties. Exceptions often exist for payments with valid business purpose, if subject to tax elsewhere, or arm's-length transactions.
questions.tip: Add-back = reverse deductions for related-party payments. Anti-income-shifting measure. Exceptions may apply.

questions.question: Affiliate nexus (attributional nexus) can be established when:

options.A: A company has any affiliate in a state
options.B: An in-state affiliate's activities are attributed to an out-of-state seller with no physical presence
options.C: Two companies share the same shareholders

questions.explanation: Affiliate nexus attributes an in-state affiliate's presence to an out-of-state seller. For example, if an online retailer has a brick-and-mortar affiliate in a state that accepts returns or promotes products, the online seller may have nexus. Click-through affiliate programs have also been nexus triggers.
questions.tip: Affiliate nexus = attribute in-state affiliate activities to out-of-state seller. Click-through affiliates also create nexus.

questions.question: Gross receipts taxes differ from income taxes in that gross receipts taxes:

options.A: Allow deductions for cost of goods sold and operating expenses
options.B: Apply to total revenue without deductions for expenses

questions.explanation: Gross receipts taxes (like Ohio's CAT or Texas's franchise tax margin version) tax total revenue with limited or no deductions for expenses. This means unprofitable businesses still owe tax. Gross receipts taxes may still be deductible on federal returns as business taxes.
questions.tip: Gross receipts tax = tax on revenue, not profit. Owed even if unprofitable. Ohio CAT, Texas margin tax examples.

questions.question: An individual can avoid statutory residency in a high-tax state by:

options.A: Changing domicile only
options.B: Spending fewer than 183 days in the state and not maintaining a permanent place of abode

questions.explanation: To avoid statutory residency, an individual typically must: (1) not maintain a permanent place of abode in the state, OR (2) spend fewer than 183 days in the state. Both conditions must be met to avoid statutory residency. Domicile is a separate analysis based on intent.
questions.tip: Break statutory residency: no permanent abode OR under 183 days. Careful tracking and documentation essential.

questions.question: The Streamlined Sales Tax (SST) Project aims to:

options.A: Create a single national sales tax
options.B: Simplify and harmonize sales tax administration across participating states
options.D: Transfer sales tax administration to the IRS

questions.explanation: The SST Project is a cooperative effort among states to simplify sales tax administration through uniform definitions, rate databases, single state-level administration, and certified service providers. Sellers using SST-certified software receive liability protection. Not all states participate.
questions.tip: SST = voluntary state cooperation for simplified sales tax. Uniform definitions, certified providers, liability protection.

questions.question: Financial institutions and airlines often use special apportionment formulas because:

options.A: They are exempt from state taxes
options.B: Standard property/payroll/sales factors don't accurately reflect their economic activity
options.C: They have no physical presence in any state

questions.explanation: Certain industries use special apportionment formulas because standard factors don't reflect their activities. Banks may use deposits or loans. Airlines use revenue passenger miles. Railroads and trucking use mileage. Broadcasting companies may use audience factors. These better reflect economic presence.
questions.tip: Special apportionment: banks (deposits), airlines (miles), broadcasters (audience). Standard factors don't fit all businesses.

questions.question: A voluntary disclosure agreement (VDA) with a state typically provides:

options.A: Complete immunity from all state taxes
options.B: Waiver of penalties and limited lookback period for unpaid taxes

questions.explanation: VDAs allow businesses that discover unreported state tax liability to come forward voluntarily. Benefits typically include penalty waiver, limited lookback period (often 3-4 years instead of full statute), and possible interest reduction. VDAs must be initiated before the state contacts the taxpayer.
questions.tip: VDA = penalty waiver + limited lookback for voluntary disclosure. Must contact state BEFORE they contact you.

questions.question: Legitimate state tax planning strategies include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.A: Locating operations in states with favorable tax regimes
options.B: Structuring transactions to avoid creating nexus where possible

questions.explanation: Legitimate planning includes location decisions, structuring to manage nexus, using available incentives, PTET elections, and timing strategies. Falsifying factor data is fraud. States actively audit apportionment factors and impose penalties for misreporting.
questions.tip: Legitimate SALT planning: location, nexus management, incentives, timing. Never falsify data - fraud penalties severe.
